creditline: Purchase through Art Quest 2003 and The William Hood Dunwoody Fund
medium: Two-panel folding screen, one of a pair, ink and color on paper
object_name: folding screen, two-panel, one of a pair
text: A renowned scholar-painter in 19th century Japan, Yamamoto Baiitsu used the difficult “boneless” technique of applying pigment directly to the paper, without outlines, or “bones, ” to impart an almost palpable delicacy to leaves and petals. As demonstrated in these screens, he also was skilled at capturing nature’s complicated profusion of flora. Unlike his predecessors, who had little firsthand knowledge of Chinese painting styles, Baiitsu had direct access to Ming dynasty bird-and-flower paintings, imported through the port city of Nagasaki.
title: Fall [right of a pair of Flowers and Insects of Spring and Fall]
